posts.post_content:
@ EvilCleavage   
  
Phage says that "If you didn't cast it from your hand, you lose the game."  
Tooth and Nail says "Put up to two creature cards from your hand onto the battlefield."  
  
Putting cards onto the battlefield is not the same thing as casting them. If you Tooth and Nailed for a Phage, you'd lose.
posts.html:
@ EvilCleavage

Phage says that "If you didn't cast it from your hand, you lose the game."
Tooth and Nail says "Put up to two creature cards from your hand onto the battlefield."

Putting cards onto the battlefield is not the same thing as casting them. If you Tooth and Nailed for a Phage, you'd lose.

posts.post_content:
*"Belz\_, you wouldn't lose the game because it isn't putting a card from your library into play. It's putting it into your hand, then into play."*   
   
No, Phage kills you unless you cast her from your hand. Even though T&N puts it from your hand into play, you still don't *cast* her.
posts.html:
"Belz_, you wouldn't lose the game because it isn't putting a card from your library into play. It's putting it into your hand, then into play."

No, Phage kills you unless you cast her from your hand. Even though T&N puts it from your hand into play, you still don't cast her.

posts.post_content:
10/4/2004 It is only considered "cast from your hand" if you cast it as a spell from your hand. Putting it onto the battlefield from your hand using a spell or ability will cause you to lose the game.  
  
Quoted from the ruling on Phage. I wish it wasn't so, but it is.
posts.html:
10/4/2004 It is only considered "cast from your hand" if you cast it as a spell from your hand. Putting it onto the battlefield from your hand using a spell or ability will cause you to lose the game.

Quoted from the ruling on Phage. I wish it wasn't so, but it is.
